nexttext:
This family of probability measures is today called a \emph{Young measure associated with the sequence} $(f_n)$.

In 1989 J. M. Ball proved the following theorem.  Let $\varOmega$ be a measurable subset of $\mathbb{R}^d$, $v\colon [0,+\infty)\to [0,+\infty)$ a continuous, nondecreasing function such \mbox{that $\lim\limits_{t\to\infty}v(t)=+\infty$. By $\psi$ we denote a function 
$\psi\colon\varOmega\times\mathbb{R}^l\ni(x,\lambda)\to\psi(x,\lambda)\in
\overline{\mathbb{R}}$} satisfying Carath\'eodory conditions: it is measurable with respect to the first, and continuous with respect to the second variable. Consider further a sequence $(f_n)$ of functions on $\varOmega$ with values in $\mathbb{R}^l$, satisfying the condition
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\int\limits_{\varOmega}\varphi(f_{n}(x))w(x)dx=\int%
\limits_{\varOmega}\int\limits_{K}\varphi(s)\nu_{x}(ds)w(x)dx:=\int\limits_{%
\varOmega}\overline{\varphi}(x)w(x)dx." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></munder><mrow><mi>φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></munder><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>K</mi></munder><mrow><mi>φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></munder><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>φ</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
This family of probability measures is today called a \emph{Young measure associated with the sequence} $(f_n)$.

In 1989 J. M. Ball proved the following theorem.  Let $\varOmega$ be a measurable subset of $\mathbb{R}^d$, $v\colon [0,+\infty)\to [0,+\infty)$ a continuous, nondecreasing function such \mbox{that $\lim\limits_{t\to\infty}v(t)=+\infty$. By $\psi$ we denote a function 
$\psi\colon\varOmega\times\mathbb{R}^l\ni(x,\lambda)\to\psi(x,\lambda)\in
\overline{\mathbb{R}}$} satisfying Carath\'eodory conditions: it is measurable with respect to the first, and continuous with respect to the second variable. Consider further a sequence $(f_n)$ of functions on $\varOmega$ with values in $\mathbb{R}^l$, satisfying the condition
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sup\limits_{n}\int\limits_{\varOmega}v(|f_{n}(x)|)dx<+\infty." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">sup</mo><mi>n</mi></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></munder><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\overline{\psi}(x)=\int\limits_{\mathbb{R}^{l}}\psi(x,\lambda)d\nu_{x}(\lambda)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>ψ</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msup><mi>ℝ</mi><mi>l</mi></msup></munder><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: defined by the formula
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="i\colon\mathcal{U}\rightarrow L^{1}(\varOmega,C(K))^{\ast}" display="block"><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>:</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒰</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>1</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>K</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>∗</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
By $Y(\varOmega ,K)$ we will denote the weak$^\ast$ closure of
the set $i(\mathcal{U})$ in $L^1(\varOmega ,C(K))^\ast$:
prevtext: defined by the formula
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle i(f),h\rangle:=\int\limits_{\varOmega}h(x,f(x))dx." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></munder><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
By $Y(\varOmega ,K)$ we will denote the weak$^\ast$ closure of
the set $i(\mathcal{U})$ in $L^1(\varOmega ,C(K))^\ast$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Y(\varOmega,K):=\Bigl{\{}L^{1}(\varOmega,C(K))^{\ast}\ni\eta:\exists(f_{n})%
\subset\mathcal{U}:i(f_{n})\xrightarrow[n\rightarrow\infty]{w^{\ast}}\eta\Bigr%
{\}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>K</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">{</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>1</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>K</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>∗</mo></msup></mrow><mo>∋</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>∃</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⊂</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒰</mi></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><munderover accent="true" accentunder="true"><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi mathsize="142%">n</mi><mo mathsize="142%" stretchy="false">→</mo><mi mathsize="142%" mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><msup><mi>w</mi><mo>∗</mo></msup></munderover><mi>η</mi></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

By the Dunford -- Pettis theorem this space is isometrically isomorphic with the space
$L^1(\varOmega ,C(K))^\ast$.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\int\limits_{K}\beta(k)d\nu_{x}(k)=\int\limits_{\varOmega}\beta(f(x))d\mu(x)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>K</mi></munder><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></munder><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Then the Young measure associated with $f$ is of the form
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f:=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\textbf{1}_{\varOmega_{i}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>:=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mtext>𝟏</mtext><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Then the Young measure associated with $f$ is of the form
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\nu_{x}=\frac{1}{M}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}\delta_{p_{i}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>M</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\int\limits_{K}\beta(k)d\nu_{n}(k)=\int\limits_{K}%
\beta(k)d\nu_{0}(k)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>K</mi></munder><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>K</mi></munder><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: This means that $(\nu_n)$ is a weak$^\ast$ Cauchy sequence, so its weak$^\ast$ accumulation point belongs to $Y(\varOmega,K)$. By the injectivity of $\psi$, there is exactly one Young measure $\rho=(\rho_x)_{x\in\varOmega}\in\mathcal{Y}(\varOmega,K)$ corresponding to this accumulation point. Then we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\Bigl{|}\int\limits_{K}\beta(k)d\nu_{n}-\int\limits_{K}\beta(k)d%
\nu_{m}\Bigr{|}=\Bigl{|}\int\limits_{\varOmega}\beta(f_{n}(x))d\mu-\int\limits%
_{\varOmega}\beta(f_{m}(x))d\mu\Bigr{|}\leq\\
\displaystyle\leq\int\limits_{\varOmega}|\beta(f_{n}(x))-\beta(f_{m}(x))|d\mu%
\leq\varepsilon\cdot\mu(\varOmega)." display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mo fence="true" maxsize="160%" nexttext:
If $P$ is a probability distribution on $\mathbb R^d$ and for some Lebesgue integrable function $g\colon\mathbb R^d\to\mathbb R$ there holds:
$\forall\, A\in\mathcal B(\mathbb R^d)\; P(A)=\int\limits_Ag(x)dx$, then the function $g$ is called a \emph{density} of $P$.

Let $\varOmega$ be a Borel subset of $\mathbb R^d$ with Lebesgue measure $M>0$. We say that random variable 
$U\colon\mathbb R^d\to\mathbb R^l$ is \emph{uniform} on $\varOmega$, if its density $g_u$ is of the form
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="P_{\varphi(X)}(C)=P(\varphi(X)^{-1}(C))=P_{X}(\varphi^{-1}(C))." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>X</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>φ</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
The probability distribution $P_U$ is then called the \emph{uniform distribution}.
\section[]{Main result}
As in the previous sections, let $\varOmega$ be an open subset of $\mathbb R^d$ with Lebesgue measure $M>0$, $d\mu(x) :=\tfrac{1}{M}dx$, where $dx$ is the $d$ -- 
dimensional Lebesgue measure on $\varOmega$ and let $K\subset\mathbb R^l$ be compact.
Denote $P:=\tfrac 1 Mdx$.

Finally, we are ready to formulate the main theorem of the article.
\begin{theorem}
Let $f\colon\mathbb R^d\supset\varOmega\rightarrow K\subset\mathbb R^l$ be a Borel function with Young measure $\mu^f$. Then $\mu^f$ is the probability distribution of the random variable $Y=f(U)$, where $U$ has a uniform distribution on $\varOmega$.
\end{theorem}
\emph{Proof.} The distribution of a random variable $Y$ is of the form:
$\forall\,C\in\mathcal B(K)$, $P_{f(U)}(C)=P_U(f^{-1}(C))$. Let $f$ be constant on $\varOmega$ with value $p$ and vanish on the complement of $\varOmega$. By lemma
\ref{aux_lemma} we have
$\mu^f=\delta_p$. For any $C\subseteq K$ we have
prevtext:
If $P$ is a probability distribution on $\mathbb R^d$ and for some Lebesgue integrable function $g\colon\mathbb R^d\to\mathbb R$ there holds:
$\forall\, A\in\mathcal B(\mathbb R^d)\; P(A)=\int\limits_Ag(x)dx$, then the function $g$ is called a \emph{density} of $P$.

Let $\varOmega$ be a Borel subset of $\mathbb R^d$ with Lebesgue measure $M>0$. We say that random variable 
$U\colon\mathbb R^d\to\mathbb R^l$ is \emph{uniform} on $\varOmega$, if its density $g_u$ is of the form
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex19.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="g_{U}(x)=\begin{cases}\tfrac{1}{M},&x\in\varOmega\\
0,&x\notin\varOmega.\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>U</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∉</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: On the other hand,
prevtext:
The probability distribution $P_U$ is then called the \emph{uniform distribution}.
\section[]{Main result}
As in the previous sections, let $\varOmega$ be an open subset of $\mathbb R^d$ with Lebesgue measure $M>0$, $d\mu(x) :=\tfrac{1}{M}dx$, where $dx$ is the $d$ -- 
dimensional Lebesgue measure on $\varOmega$ and let $K\subset\mathbb R^l$ be compact.
Denote $P:=\tfrac 1 Mdx$.

Finally, we are ready to formulate the main theorem of the article.
\begin{theorem}
Let $f\colon\mathbb R^d\supset\varOmega\rightarrow K\subset\mathbb R^l$ be a Borel function with Young measure $\mu^f$. Then $\mu^f$ is the probability distribution of the random variable $Y=f(U)$, where $U$ has a uniform distribution on $\varOmega$.
\end{theorem}
\emph{Proof.} The distribution of a random variable $Y$ is of the form:
$\forall\,C\in\mathcal B(K)$, $P_{f(U)}(C)=P_U(f^{-1}(C))$. Let $f$ be constant on $\varOmega$ with value $p$ and vanish on the complement of $\varOmega$. By lemma
\ref{aux_lemma} we have
$\mu^f=\delta_p$. For any $C\subseteq K$ we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mu^{f}(C)=\int\limits_{\mathbb{R}^{l}}\textbf{1}_{C}(p)d\delta_{p}=\begin{%
cases}1,&p\in C\\
0,&p\notin C.\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>μ</mi><mi>f</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msup><mi>ℝ</mi><mi>l</mi></msup></munder><mrow><msub><mtext>𝟏</mtext><mi>C</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>∉</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: On the other hand,
text:
\[
P_U(f^{-1}(C))=\int\limits_{f^{-1}(C)}g_udP=\frac 1 M\int\limits_{\{x:f(x)\in C\}}dx=
\begin{cases}
\tfrac 1 M\cdot M=1, & p\in C\\
\tfrac 1 M\cdot 0=0, & p\notin C.
\end{cases}
\]
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex21.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="P_{U}(f^{-1}(C))=\int\limits_{f^{-1}(C)}g_{u}dP=\frac{1}{M}\int\limits_{\{x:f(%
x)\in C\}}dx=\begin{cases}\tfrac{1}{M}\cdot M=1,&p\in C\\
\tfrac{1}{M}\cdot 0=0,&p\notin C.\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>U</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>u</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>P</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>M</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⋅</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⋅</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>∉</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>
